concept.title: History of DITA
concept.shortdesc: Here you will find a short history of DITA and how it has affected the world of technical communication.

conbody.p: With the invention of the XML - or, eXtensible markup language - in the mid 1990's, IBM worked to develop a program through which XML could be processed for documentation. Thus, DITA was born in 2001 to simplify XML and allow it to be used as a language for documentation. The DITA maps were especially significant in that they organized and outlined content like never before.

The next addition to DITA, in 2002, was the Open Toolkit, which added domain specialization to the already created topic specialization through a set of XSLT stylesheets. IBM encouraged the integration of Open Toolkit to publish DITA, and many vendors have followed suit over the years. This Toolkit was donated to SourceForge in 2005 where it is continutally maintained by IBM, however it is not a part of the DITA Standards efforts through OASIS.

The following year, IBM published the second edition of "Developing Quality Technical Information", a great tool for reference about DITA. This edition included in introduction which specified the uses of tasks, concepts, references, etc. which had not been done before. One interesting note about this book is that it describes DITA, in detail, serving as an almost completely necessary resource for anyone using DITA, yet it never mentions the name "DITA", as IBM was using it internally at the time.

To make DITA a public product, the "Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards, or, Oasis, created a committee to explore the standardization of DITA. This committee includes XML tool vendors, consultants on "Information Architecture and Content Management Systems", and others that work together to maintain the DITA standards as it becomes more widely used.
